bibl.title: Letter from Eduardo Angles to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 19, 1941

div1.p: Angles explains why Cubans are fearful that Finlay will be robbed of his glory.

div1.head: Letter from Eduardo Angles to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 19, 1941
div1.opener:
p. 1.
DR. EDUARDO ANGLES
MEDICO CIRUJANO
-----
GENERAL LEE NO. 19.
TELEFONO FO-7163
MARIANAO
-----
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
February 19, 1941
Brig. Gen. Jefferson Randolph Kean
2804 N St. N.W.
Washington, D.C.
My dear Dr. Kean:
div1.p:
I've had the pleasure of receiving your very nice letter and
hurry on to answer with deep gratitude, for in it you again ex-
press your great feelings and your just way of thinking.

Very interesting what you explain about memory--Naturally I
agree with you that when one has written reports that makes
things final.

I'll first refer to the San Jose Farm belonging to Dr. L.G. Rojas
which you call Camp Lazear. I had no knowledge of the fact
that Americans designated the farm thus for I knew San José
Farm as the first place used for Reed Commission work. I went
there a few times with Reed, Carrol, Lazear and saw the Barrack he was dead! PSH
that was constructed for experiments with infested cloth and
laboratory work on the bacilus icteroides. A short time after
the Commission demonstrated the non-existence of this bacillus
with the various experiments. Then after this, quite a while
later, the meeting took place celebrated by you, Major Gorgas,
so esteemed among us, and Gral. Wood who placed at your disposal
the amount of $10.000 to start the experiments with the theory
of Dr. Finlay. After took place the meeting with Dr. Finlay,
Reed, you and Gorgas. The preliminary speech by Dr. Reed in
said meeting was published in “Philadelphia Journal” of Oct. 27,
1900. It reads thus: “We wish to express our most sincere thanks
to Dr. Finlay for the delightful interview he gave us and for
placing at our disposal his diverse publications on Yellow Fever
during the past 20 years and also the eggs of the species of
mosquitos with which he had made his several incubations. With
them, that is, with the mosquitos obtained in this manner, we
made our first experiments. These demonstrations were sent to
Mr. L.A. Howard, etymologist of the Dept. of Agriculture in Wash-
ington and they were identified as the culex faciatus Fabr.

After celebrating this interview you say Reed left for Wash-
ington and came back in October and you returned to San Jose
Farm where you put up tents for these experiments. This I did
not know for in the Alturas Farm of Father Zamora in the back
of Columbia Hospital past the street car line of Marianao you set ✓
up a camp with small houses for the Yellow Fever cases. I saw
you here in this camp with Dr. Carrol, Lazear and the soldier,
Dean, of the 7th Cavalry and since Lazear died in this camp I had
thought that in no other place would a monument be more suitably
placed---a monument to a man who sacrifized himself for science and
no!!no!P.S.H.
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
p. 2
DR. EDUARDO ANGLES
MEDICO CIRUJANO
-----
GENERAL LEE NO. 19.
TELEFONO FO-7163
MARIANAO
Note. It was Major Reed who named his experimental camp
after Dr. Lazear and the Americans have always used this name
for it-JRK
-Page 2-
for humanity. This I thought should be the spot called Camp
Lazear since it was where he died and because Lazear had no
relation whatsoever with the San José Farm. All the co-
mmissions that have come to Cuba to see the place where Lazear
died have been taken there by me and Cuban authorities. This
is the explanation why I and the Cuban authorities consider it
as Camp Lazear.

In respect to my mistake in naming you as one of the sick in
Quemados I'll say that I mentioned you as the resident in no. 27
next to where I lived and didn't recall Major Edmunds. The
important thing is that there was a case of Yellow Fever there.

You tell me in your letter that you have been surprized that
Cubans have the idea that Americans intend to rob the great
Finlay of his glory. The origin of that fear rests in the dis-
cription on the bronze bust of the great Dr. Reed in the Capitol
of Washington which reads: “To Major Reed discoverer of the
transmission of Yellow Fever by the mosquito.” Those that have
seen the epigraph consider it inadecuate and there lies the
origin of the doubt in some. It is my opinion that it is im-
possible to pretend another than Finlay to be the one who dis-
covered and proved the transmission of Yellow Fever by the mos-
quito since 1881. But as you say Dr. Reed with greater advan-
tages was able to follow Finlay's technique and prove it. Here
nobody takes away any merit from the commission, Dr. Gorgas and
you, who with such good faith and capacity worked to benefit so
greatly Cuba and America with this discovery.
See in closure
of Feb 25 1941

Dr. Finlay like all discoverers had his drawbacks, the same as
Jenner, Miguel Servet in 1853, Pasteur, Galileo and others, but
at the end history does them justice proclaiming their glory and
courage. I always admired Dr. Reed and Lazear, martyr of science,
Agramonte was very young, Carrol very instructed and serious--You
delighted me with your activity, your amiability and medical ca-
pacity. I believe those who worked most were Dr. Gorgas and you.
I would have liked that American intervention of 1900 to have last-
ed 10 years more for the moral and material health of our Cuban
people. It would have done a lot of good because of the quality
and honorability of its members.

Please pardon if any word in this letter should offend you---
Scratch it our for I only feel admiration and respect to-
wards you. If your health is good come to my house here in
Cuba...you have a room and are welcomed by me and my children.

DR. EDUARDO ANGLES
MEDICO CIRUJANO
-----
GENERAL LEE NO. 19.
TELEFONO FO-7163
MARIANAO
-----

Two years ago I wrote you and told you the sad news of the
death of my son Eddy, who was under your orders during
the Pershing Expedition. He was of the National Guard.
After that I wrote you another letter and still the same,--
no answer. In Christmas I sent you my best wishes but so
far I haven't had the pleasure of hearing from you. Do
tell me if you received them..also a book by Dr. Dominguez
Roldan.
div1.closer: Your friend sincerely, Dr. Ed Angles, Dr. Eduardo Angles
